trial_identification.studytitle: Hepatitis B Acceptability and Vaccination Incentive Trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial to evaluate the effectiveness of a small financial incentive after the second and third dose of a Hepatitis B vaccine on vaccine completion in people who inject drugs.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other inflammatory or immune system disorders

interventions.interventions: Provision of a small financial incentives i.e. $30 will be given after the participant receives the second dose and $30 after the participant receives the third dose of Hepatitis B vaccine. Incentives will be given to participants randomised to the incentive arm only.
interventions.comparator: no financial incentive as per standard care

primaryOutcome.outcome: Determine relative to a standard care control condition the efficacy of incentive payments to increase Hepatitis B Vaccine (HBV) completion using an accelerated schedule (0, 7 and 21 days). Accelerated schedule i.e. receipt of all 3 Hepatitis B vaccinations in a shorter timeframe in comparison to the conventional schedule ( 0,1 and 6 months).

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Assess the cost effectiveness of incentive payments relative to 'standard care' as a method of improving vaccine induced immunity as measured at 12 weeks and rates of successful series completion.The cost effectiveness analysis (CEA) will compare the marginal and incremental costs and outcomes of standard care with the incentive payment arm.
Identify the correlates of immunity(defined as hepatitis B surface antibody levels > =10mIU/ml at 12 weeks post intervention in this group.This will be assessed by blood analysis.

Assess the acceptability of vaccines including HBV vaccines; barriers to immunisation uptake and willingness to participate in vaccine trials among people who inject drugs(PWID). All behavioural data will be collected using Audio Computer-Assisted Self Interview (ACASI) technology at baseline and at week 12 which has been associated with higher reports of sensitive and stigmatized behaviours among PWID, adolescents and HIV positive people (Des Jarlais et al. 1999; Metzger et al. 2000).
Assess hepatitis B related knowledge in this group using the study-specific instrument (Day et al. 2003).

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1) Aged 16 years and above; 2) Injected drugs at least once in the preceding 6 months; 3) No previous hepatitis B infection, and a maximum of one previous dose of hepatitis B vaccination, or unknown infection and vaccination status, based on self-report and, where available medical records; 4) ability to provide informed consent, to be randomised and attend vaccinations over a period of 3 weeks and attend follow up at 12 weeks post randomisation.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Evidence of natural or vaccine induced immunity; 2) Previous exposure or two+ vaccinations (as identified by self report), where HBV surface antibody =10 mIU/ml; 3) Serious mental or physical illness or disability likely to impact on capacity to complete the study procedures; 4) Insufficient English language skills that will impair ability to give informed consent or provide reliable responses to study interviews/questionnaires; 5) Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection; 6) Refusal to be vaccinated against hepatitis B.

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation: Statistical Analysis Software (SAS) implementation of randomisation will be used with RANUNI (the SAS command which creates random numbers from uniform distribution. It generates random numbers between 01 and 1) function.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This trial seeks to investigate if providing a small financial incentive ($30) will increase the uptake and completion of the hepatitis B vaccine among injecting drug users.
